g.text: So we have text files in some programming language
We want to do something useful with that text file
So we have to "parse" the text of that textfile into some sort of structures
This is known as parsing. The jargon for this process is known as a parsor
For a big language this parser is divided into two phases
First Phase is where the text of
the text file is split into a stream
of tokens and then the parser assembles
these tokens into a structure( like a grammar)
tokens are
like keywords
operators, etc
Sometimes this phase
is not necessary
The parsed structure is often called a “syntax tree”.
One can simply simulate the program from the syntax tree.
This is called an “interpreter”, and it’s a naive interpreter
A less naive interpreter includes extra steps.
Such as converting the syntax tree into a list
of instructions called “bytecode”.
The execution of a program works on the bytecode
instead of the syntax tree
The component for producing the bytecode is also called a “compiler”, and the line
between compiler and interpreter blurs from here. A compiler such as GCC ultimately
outputs a binary executable — a container for machine code — which also contains a list
of instructions, the real instructions that the CPU executes.
